School District of Summerhills

Protestant Public School District No. 34 of the Northwest Territories.

WHEREAS it is considered desirable to have a total sum of FIVE HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS for the more commodious School District for the ensuing school year, and the same intended for the following purposes, viz: purchasing of books, setting and grading the same, etc., and also the payment of the teacher's salary, which is fixed at one hundred and seventy-five dollars per year, the undersigned does hereby sign his name to this contract, the terms and conditions of which are stated herein:

The undersigned does hereby agree to teach the district school during the ensuing school year, and to perform all the duties of the teacher required by law, and in consideration thereof, he will be paid the sum of one hundred and seventy-five dollars per year.

Done at Summerhills this 15th day of March, 1886.

(Signed) John Smith

Board of Trustees of Summerhills School District

**WOULDN'T LIKE TO KNOW.**

The Fort Garry Typotheque Violette has a very special article which we have been unable to find anywhere else. It is entitled "That Contract." Our contemporary has no doubt heard that we have been engaged to do certain jobs at printing, but being unsuccessful in proving them to be business, it seems that here is a venture and make certain statements with the object not of drawing us out, but the Violette has mistaken us. We will not be in the drawing room just at present. We will tell our colleagues in other columns by January 1st that we have not been engaged to do certain jobs at printing, but being unsuccessful in proving them to be business, it seems that here is a venture and make certain statements with the object not of drawing us out, but the Violette has mistaken us.

---

**FROM THE CAPITAL.**

Ottawa, March 4.—In the Commons yesterday Mr. Thompson moved an amendment to the Royal Proclamation of the Northwest Territories. Mr. Watson presented a petition of Thomas C. Steele and others, urging the Government to send representatives to the Indians in the east and west. The motion was carried.

---

**INDIAN AFFAIRS.**

**Synopsis of the Departmental Annual Report.**

Ottawa, March 2.—The report of the Department of Indian Affairs for the year ending December 31, 1885, was to be laid down by the table by Sir John Macdonald. The Superintendent-General stated that he had instructed the Indians to go to work and to cease their raids.

---

**Teacher Wanted.**

For Sunnyside School District, desire experienced teacher. Must have satisfactory references and satisfy requirements of the Board of Education.
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of One Dollar, with the object of securing advance payment. We can much better afford to publish a paper at that rate than when we find that every paper goes out unpaid for, than if we took the chances of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides we will thus specially secure a larger circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1877.

Morris,

Correspondence.

Sir, — If I can again prevail, or ever these petitions imposed upon your kindness, by leaving some of the prominent members of any valuable business organization at a closed firm, their claims for what they shall get for those whom there are I believe some such — and there are some who have been like this for many months past, I can find no means to force the right side of my mouth upon the town before me. Their claims are not only worthy, but overdue. The officers of the Qapelle Valley Farming Co., and when their claims have been honored, the best interest of the community will be served. It is a great sacrifice to the farmers at this time to give up their claims to those who have been so generous. They have not yet been paid off.

The Barn Farm has not been treated justly in its requests. We shall see who will really benefit from this scheme. Will it be fair? Will it be just? Will it be practical?

Looking forward to a brighter future, we must stand together and defend the cause of the much abused Indian. Their demands may seem unreasonable, but justice should be done to them.

J. McEwan,
General Blacksmith,
Qu'Appelle.

Q'APPELLE SUSTAINABLE.
Rapid City Ripples.

If charter would build a railway, Rapid City would have had one more or long ago. Two charters are now asked for from Parliament, one calling for a railway in this place. One is called the Brandon and Hudson's Bay and Edmonton Railway Company, and the other is the removal of the Northwest Central.

The last number of the Winnipeg Chamber says: "The Rapid City Standard has just been published. The best thing now doing about the Editor did not know what it was writing about. The Standard was published in 1883, and has since appeared under- rapidly. Will the Commercial please correct?"

It would seem as if the North-West Central Railway Co., were in earnest about building a portion of their road this year. Their act of incorporation declares that they should build fifty miles in 1885, and seventy miles each succeeding year till completed. Mr. Jas. Austin, of the North-West Central, Co., has introduced an Act in the Dominion Parliament to extend the charter for another twenty-five miles. That means that the Co. will be able to build 120 miles this year. If the work is done as construction goes on, it is reasonable to think that the Co. would make good its claim for renewal of their charter for one year only, unless they intended to go on.

On Feb. 27th meeting was held at the Queen's hotel for the purpose of organizing a Liberal Conservative Association. Mr. S. D. Currie was appointed Chairman, and motions and by-laws for the government of the association were read, adopted and sent to those places. The following members were elected officers for the ensuing year: President, Alfred Ross; Vice-President, G. L. Stone; Secretary-Treasurer, Thomas Huggett. Executive Committee: Messrs. M. T. Ford, W. Hooper George Humber, Jas. Burland, Miss. Grammitz, Tom Huckle.

Mr. Currie, in his address, gave short addresses thanking the members for the honour done them, urging upon them the duty of cooperation and organization, and reviewing the policy of the Conservative Government as being progressive and to the very best interests of the country.

Vick's Floral Guide for 1886, the pioneer seed annual of America, comes out this year in a booklet, not a dry list of hard botanical names, but over thirty pages of illustrations and descriptions of articles on Roses, House Plants, Cheap Greenhouses, Onion Culture, Muscari and Manure, Flower Gardening, and very interesting and charming, followed by about 150 pages containing illustrations of everything the heart could desire in the line of Seeds, Plants, Bulbs, Potatoes, etc., &c., &c. It is a book easy to afford to publish, and really give away this beautiful work for only 20¢. It will be found, with hundreds of illustrations and two fine Colored Plates, all enclosed in an elegant cover, that the purchaser of this guide cannot do better than send him 10 cents for the Floral Guide, to James Vick, P.O. Box 409, Rochester, N. Y. Deduct the 10 cents. Order first order sent for seeds.

CONSUMPTION CURED.

Act 41 of the Victorian laws, from practical having had placed in the hands of the Indian missionary the formula of a simple vegetable remedy for the specific consumption of man and beast. With the aid of this formula, Mr. J. A. Jackson, late of Perth, Australia, and all absent and long afflicted with pulmonary consumption, Nervous debility and all forms of Nervous complaints, after having tested its wonderful curative qualities on himself, was enabled to bring it known to the suffering fellow-men. Assailed by this malady and unable to stand the tortures of consumption, he took up this formula, and by constant use of it, he was enabled to change, in all who knew him, this disease into health, strength and vigour. Sent me by addressing with stamp, making this post paid. M. A. Norman.

AVIS.

A new set up in present house, No. 156 Main Street, Rapid City, the North West Central Railway Company, Limited, (a new company) have decided to erect a new depot and yards, and to combine the old Atlantic and Pacific Railway Company, Limited, and the North West Central Railway Company, Limited, for the purpose of constructing a railway from this place to the north-western part of the province. For this purpose, the company have purchased the land on which the new depot and yards will be erected, and have engaged the services of a competent engineer to superintend the construction of the road.

Notice.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an application will be made on behalf of the North West Central Railway Company, Limited, for an extension of the charter of said company, authorizing said company to construct a railway from this place to the north-western part of the province, and to operate the same for ten years thereafter, or for such longer period as said company may desire, subject to such terms and conditions as may be imposed by the Board of Directors.

JAMES BRAY,

President of the N. W. C. R. Co.

HOME & GOSSIP.
QU'APPELLE.

—Scops mild.
—The Pancake offers to new two doors north of the Queen's hotel.
—New building is to be put up for a bakery at Qu'Appelle street.
—The dying column, under ten minutes, will hang here about Applica.
—The Queen's hotel has been connected with the P. R. station by telephone.
—A fire was held Wednesday (Ash Wednesday) morning in St. Peter's church.
—A correspondent asks us whether or not nuts and some stones constitute a loaf of bread.
—We will come tomorrow to taste our stock of Stirling sleighs in Mr. H. F. Murray's yard.
—We have been compelled to cut some of our matter short this week on account of the confusion of newspapers.
—The freighters who are engaged in handling the seed grain from Qu'Appelle to Prince Albert get 5¢ per bushel.
—A very pleasant and successful ballet social was given at the residence of Mr. G. H. V. Bulyea last Friday evening.
—R. Battery Garrison Dramatic Club have their entertainment on the 17th of next, St. Patrick's day.
—Furnish will be held Saturday, March 26th.
—Thos. Dodge, M.P., has purchased from Mr. C. A. Odom the half mile Head, Tr. 18, Range 14, at $50 per acre. This is a good investment as there are crops on the Qu'Appelle town site.
—The Non-Commissioned officers and men of Jackie's, R.C.A., are very thankful for the sympathy extended by St. Peter's church, for their kindness in sending them some note paper and envelopes.
—We omitted last week to say that Mr. D. Legay, the tonsorial artist, has returned from a trip to Winnipeg and St. Paul. He has found his place of business opposite the Queen's hotel, where he will henceforth, you in the most commodious fashion.
—Powdernook and eleven of the Bridgedale relief prisoners passed through the town on Thursday evening.
—On Saturday last Rev. Faith Lemonbe accompanied them. On Tuesday morning Powdernook and Mr. Harrower came down from Regina.
—A group photograph of the above mentioned persons was published in the Fort Qu'Appelle Express.
—"In regard to my being no honest man," presumably the editor himself if he wrote the article, he said last week shortly before the editorial board had a question asked from him, and his last note contained a still more insulting instance. He does a Jew's dance, make me laugh why the name of their P. O. should not be changed to that of the owner of this establishment where things cost less because their mail matter when addressed to Qu'Appelle?" I am sure we do not send out a second piece of mail ever since he could be suffered no more evasions by his correspondences, as he gives the general impression of a Statesman, than art a jewel." The fact was that it was a convenient place, the proper address being on the other, and spouse of the inconvenience to himself still the Visitors fairly holds us responsible. "Has such a description caused you
GARRISON THEATRICALS.

There was a very large attendance at the Garrison Theatre again on Monday evening in the magnificent building, in aid of St. Peter's Church. Hon. James Gibbon, ex-Minister of Justice and Mr. Macdonald honored the occasion by their presence. The beautiful display of fireworks and pyrotechnic effects between General Middleton and Powdermaker, painted by Capt. Ruthven, who certainly displayed his claim as a powderhouse manufacturer in a very handsome manner. The first act, "Sweet as a cucumber," was exceedingly well done and displayed the acting talent of the company. Miss Eliza Short acted "Florine," who had been sent abroad by her father to overcome her lovesickness. Her coquettishness was amazing under the situations presented. Capt. Ruthven took the part of "Old Barkins" and acted it most effectively. "Phoenix" came into prominence; however, early rated highly by the spectators. The second act again displayed the acting talent of the company in an enjoyable manner.
ST. JOHNS COLLEGE, QU'APPELLE STATION.

March 19th, 1883.

TO THE EDITOR:

Sir.—It is internally difficult to make a speech in the midst of a general excelsis, and the desire was to hear something that would reach the ears of all present. When Mr. Pope rose to reply to our toast, it was impossible to make a speech. However I hope that you will allow me to express my satisfaction throughout, the memory of your enthusiasm, and to offer to Major Short Maguire, Esq., Brevet Lieut., for his admirable skill and pains which he displayed in the management of his business. I think it is desirable that this should be done, both for the loss of reputations for the valuable assistance given to the Institution at its maturity, and for the kind co-operation which you have shown through your unwearied interest and constant attention to the affairs for which your presence made the whole half. With many apologies for encroaching on your space.

Yours obediently,
FRED W. PELLEY.

BARCARRIS.

Miss Ella Johnston is visiting with her brother at Fort Qu'Appelle. They are situated overlooking the town lake.
Mrs. Wilson has returned from her home to her parents in Regina, where she resides with the gases of Mr. Robert Webster.

—Mr. Richard Calman has returned from Browning to increasing his goods to Fort Qu'Appelle, who has purchased an ice cream, and has been making cheese this season.

—Tom Dobbs is visiting Mr. J. McFarlane and appears to be in fine health condition, and the cause of these results is greatly strengthened in the neighborhood.

INDIAN HEAD.

Mr. Joe MacDonald has taken a trip East to Wapella for a few weeks.

—Mr. Haney Haughton, former Premier, visited Qu'Appelle last Monday.

Mr. J. A. Quimby is incorporating a new store building just opened by Mr. J. McFarlane.

—Mr. J. McFarlane, assisted by Mr. Richard Webb, packed three cart-loads of vegetables into a house.

—Mr. A. J. Dunlop was appointed to collect our Butterage, header. He reported that it was unsold and that a new header would be required.

EDMONTON.
